case_name: Union of India and Northern Frontier Railway v. M/s. Ladu Lal Jain

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 717 of 1961 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 717 of 1961.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated April 10, 1961 of Assam High Court in Civil Revision No. 10 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 10, 1961 of the Assam High Court in Civil Revision No. 10 of 1961.

facts.text: Assam High Court rejected revision application under s.115 CPC against order of Additional Subordinate Judge, Gauhati.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, by special leave, is directed against the order of the High Court of Assam rejecting the revision application, under s. 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure, hereinafter called the Code, of the appellants against the order of the Additional Subordinate, Judge, Gauhati,

facts.text: Money suit instituted by plaintiff-respondent against Union of India and Northern Frontier Railway represented by General Manager at Pandu.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was instituted by the plaintiff -respondent against the Union of India and the Northern Frontier Railway represented by the General Manager, having its headquarters at Pandu.

facts.text: Claim for recovery of Rs. 8,250/- due to non-delivery of goods consigned to M/s. Ladu Lal Jain.

anchor.surface_text: It related to a claim for recovery of a sum of Rs. 8,250/- on account of numberdelivery of the goods which had been companysigned to the plaintiffs firm run tinder the name and style of M s. Ladu Lal Jain.

facts.text: 134 bags of rice booked from Kalyanganj station to Kanki station on April 13, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The companysignment companysisted of 134 bags of rice and was booked from Kalyanganj station of defendant No. 2 for carriage to Kanki station of the same defendant on April 13, 1958.

facts.text: Goods not delivered to plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: The goods companysigned were number delivered to the plaintiff and hence the suit,

facts.text: Notice under s.77 Indian Railways Act and s.80 CPC served on defendant railway.

anchor.surface_text: after serving a numberice under s. 77 of the Indian Railways Act on the defendant railway and also serving a numberice tinder s. 80 of the Code.

facts.text: Plaintiff alleged cause of action arose at Pandu within jurisdiction of Gauhati Court.

anchor.surface_text: It was alleged in the plaint that the cause of action arose at Pandu within the jurisdiction of the Court at Gauhati,

facts.text: Northern Frontier Railway headquarters at Pandu, within Gauhati Court jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: the place where numberice under s. 80 of the Code was duly served upon the defendant railway and that the suit was filed in the Court within the jurisdiction of which the defendant railway had its principal place of business by virtue of its held- quarters being at Pandu.

facts.text: Defendants filed joint written statement.

anchor.surface_text: The two defendants filed a joint written statement.

facts.text: Kalyanganj is in West Bengal, Kanki in Bihar, Gauhati in Assam.

anchor.surface_text: Kalyanganj is in West Bengal and Kanki is in the State of Bihar. Gauhati is in the State of Assam.

facts.text: Defendants contended Gauhati Court has no territorial jurisdiction as stations not within its jurisdiction and consignment never travelled in Assam.

anchor.surface_text: It was companytended inter alia that Gauhati Court had numberterritorial jurisdiction to try the suit as neither of the aforesaid railway stations was within its jurisdiction and that the companysignment never travelled within any part of the State of Assam

facts.text: Defendants contended service of notice does not vest territorial jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: It was further companytended that mere service of numberice, which was number admitted, on the defendants at a place within the jurisdiction of the Court, companyld number vest territorial jurisdiction on it

facts.text: Union of India has no principal place of business at Pandu, headquarters at New Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: and that defendant No. 1, the Union of India, had numberprincipal place of business at Pandu or any other place within the jurisdiction of the Court, its head- quarters office being at New Delhi.

facts.text: Northern Frontier Railway owned and managed by Union of India, Pandu office is branch controlled from New Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: It was also stated that defendant No. 2 is owned and managed by defendant No. 1, that the office of defendant No. 2 at Pandu was also owned and companytrolled by defendant No. 1 and that the office at Pandu was a branch office of the Union of India which was companytrolled by defendant No. I from New Delhi.

facts.text: Trial Court held it had jurisdiction relying on P.C. Biswas v. Union of India.

anchor.surface_text: Relying on the case reported as P.C. Biswas v. Union of India  1 , the Trial Court decided the preliminary issue about jurisdiction against the defendants holding that the principal place from which the railway administrator- in a particular area is carried on is the principal place of business for the purpose of s. 20 of the  ode.

facts.text: High Court single judge rejected revision on same basis.

anchor.surface_text: The single judge of the High Court rejected the revision also on the basis of the same decision of his Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on May 7, 1963 by Raghubar Dayal J.

anchor.surface_text: R. Prem, P. D. Menon for R. N. Sachthey, for the appellants. The respondent did number appear. 1963. May 7. The judgment of the Court was delivered by RAGHUBAR DAYAL J.

facts.text: Appellants' contention: running of railways by Union of India is not carrying on business.

anchor.surface_text: The sole companytention raised for the appellants in this Court is that the running of railways by the Union of India cannot be said to amount to its carrying on business

facts.text: No allegation in written statement that Government is not running railways for profit.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberallegation in the written statement that the Government is number running railways for profit. No issue was framed about it.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Union of India carries on business of running railways and can be sued at Gauhati where headquarters of Northern Frontier Railway is situated.

anchor.surface_text: In view of what we have said above, we hold that the, Union of India carries on the business of running railways and can be sued in the Court of the Subordinate Judge of Gauhati within whose territorial jurisdiction the headquarters of one of the railways run by the Union is situated.

issues.text: Whether the running of railways by the Union of India amounts to its carrying on business such that the headquarters of the Northern Frontier Railway Administration at Pandu gives jurisdiction to the Court at Gauhati under s. 20 of the Code

anchor.surface_text: The sole contention raised for the appellants in this Court is that the running of railways by the Union of India cannot be said to amount to its carrying on business and that therefore the fact that the headquarters of the Northern Frontier Railway Administration is at Pandu within the jurisdiction of the Court at Gauhati does not give the Court jurisdiction under s. 20 of the Code.

issues.text: Whether profit making is a necessary element for a government undertaking to constitute carrying on business

anchor.surface_text: The contention is based on the reasoning that any undertaking run by the Government, even if it amounts to the carrying on of a business when run by a private individual, would not be the carrying on of business by the Government if there was no element of profit making in it.

issues.text: Whether mere service of notice under s. 80 of the Code at a place vests territorial jurisdiction in the court there

anchor.surface_text: It was further contended that mere service of notice, which was not admitted, on the defendants at a place within the jurisdiction of the Court, could not vest territorial jurisdiction on it

issues.text: Whether the nature and character of the activity of running railways defines it as business irrespective of who conducts it or the motive

anchor.surface_text: It is the nature of the activity which defines its character. Running of railways is such an activity which comes within the expression business.

issues.text: Whether running railways is a sovereign function or a commercial business activity

anchor.surface_text: Certain activities will undoubtedly be regarded as public services, as for instance, those undertaken in the exercise of the sovereign power of the State

arguments.claim: No allegation in written statement that Government not running railways for profit; no issue framed; cannot presume no profit motive

anchor.surface_text: There is no allegation in the written statement that the Government is not running railways for profit. No issue was framed about it.

arguments.claim: Government can carry on business; 'carries on business' applies even if other expressions like resides do not fit government

anchor.surface_text: The Government can however carry on business. The mere fact that the expression carries on business is used along with the other expressions, does not mean that it would apply only to such persons to whom the other two expressions regarding residence or of personally working for gain would apply.

arguments.claim: Running of railways is business defined by nature of activity, not by who runs it or motive

anchor.surface_text: It is the nature of the activity which defines its character. Running of railways is such an activity which comes within the expression business. The fact as to who runs it and with what motive cannot affect it.

arguments.claim: Profit element not necessary ingredient of carrying on business though usually for profit

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that profit element is not a necessary ingredient of carrying on business, though usually business is carried on for profit.

arguments.claim: Activity character same whether by private or government per Hospital Mazdoor Sabha, Nagpur Corp precedents

anchor.surface_text: In State of Bombay v. The Hospital Mazdoor Sabha the question was whether... It is the character of the activity which decides... who conducts the activity and whether it is conducted for profit or not do not make a material difference.

arguments.claim: Running railways commercial activity, not sovereign public service per Satya Narain
Director of Rationing case inapplicable as rationing sovereign duty, not business
Union of India carries on business of running railways and suable at Gauhati court where Northern Frontier Railway headquarters situated

anchor.surface_text: In view of what we have said above, we hold that the Union of India carries on the business of running railways and can be sued in the Court of the Subordinate Judge of Gauhati within whose territorial jurisdiction the headquarters of one of the railways run by the Union is situated.

holdings.text: the Union of India carries on the business of running railways and can be sued in the Court of the Subordinate Judge of Gauhati within whose territorial jurisdiction the headquarters of one of the railways run by the Union is situated.

anchor.surface_text: In view of what we have said above, we hold that the, Union of India carries on the business of running railways and can be sued in the Court of the Subordinate Judge of Gauhati within whose territorial jurisdiction the headquarters of one of the railways run by the Union is situated.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Union runs railways as business per nature of activity irrespective of conductor or motive; constitutional provisions permit; precedents on industry and public service distinguish; headquarters is principal place of business under s.20 CPC analogous to Explanation II.

holdings.text: profit element is not a necessary ingredient of carrying on business, though usually business is carried on for profit.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that profit element is number a necessary ingredient of carrying on business, though usually business is carried on for profit. It is to be presumed that the Railways are run on a profit basis, though it may be that occasionally they are run at a loss.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No allegation or issue on lack of profit motive; cannot presume absence; profit usual but not essential even for government undertakings.

holdings.text: It is the nature of the activity which defines its character. Running of railways is such an activity which comes within the expression business. The fact as to who runs it and with what motive cannot affect it.

anchor.surface_text: It is the nature of the activity which defines its character. Running of railways is such an activity which comes within the expression business. The fact as to who runs it and with what motive cannot affect it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Character determined by activity itself, applying rationale from Hospital Mazdoor Sabha and Nagpur Corporation cases where state activity treated same as private.

holdings.text: The Government can however carry on business. The mere fact that the expression carries on business is used along with the other expressions, does number mean that it would apply only to such persons to whom the other two expressions regarding residence or of personally working for gain would apply.

anchor.surface_text: The Government can however carry on business. The mere fact that the expression carries on business is used along with the other expressions, does number mean that it would apply only to such persons to whom the other two expressions regarding residence or of personally working for gain would apply.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'Carries on business' in s.20 CPC applies to government despite inapplicability of 'resides' or 'personally works for gain'; supported by Art.298 and Art.19(6).

holdings.text: The fact that the Government runs the railways for providing quick and cheap transport for people and goods and for strategic reasons will number companyvert what amounts to the carrying on of a business into an activity of the State as a sovereign body.

anchor.surface_text: The fact that the Government runs the railways for providing quick and cheap transport for people and goods and for strategic reasons will number companyvert what amounts to the carrying on of a business into an activity of the State as a sovereign body.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Beneficial or strategic purposes do not alter commercial business character; distinguished from sovereign duties like rationing per precedents; railways pure business undertaking.

precedents.citation: P.C. Biswas v. Union of India  1

anchor.surface_text: P.C. Biswas v. Union of India  1

precedents.case_name: P.C. Biswas v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: the principal place from which the railway administrator in a particular area is carried on is the principal place of business for the purpose of s. 20 of the Code

precedents.citation: State of Bombay v. The Hospital Mozdoor Sabha 1

anchor.surface_text: State of Bombay v. The Hospital Mozdoor Sabha 1

precedents.case_name: State of Bombay v. Hospital Mazdoor Sabha
precedents.cited_proposition: the character of the activity involved in running a hospital brings it within the definition of industry under s. 2(j) of the Industrial Disputes Act regardless of whether run by government or private and profit motive
precedents.cited_holding: Thus the character of the activity involved in running a hospital brings the institution of the hospital within s. 2(j). Does it make any difference that the hospital is run by the Government ... It is the character of the activity which decides

precedents.citation: The Corporation of the City of Nagpur v. Its employees  1 1960 a S.C.R. 942, 962

anchor.surface_text: The Corporation of the City of Nagpur v. Its employees  1 1960 a S.C.R. 942, 962

precedents.case_name: Corporation of the City of Nagpur v. Its Employees
precedents.cited_proposition: if a service rendered by an individual or private person would be an industry, it would equally be an industry when rendered by a corporation or municipality; monetary considerations not essential
precedents.cited_holding: If a service rendered by an individual or a private person would be an industry, it would equally be an industry in the hands of a corporation. ... Monetary considerations for service is, therefore, not an essential characteristic of industry

precedents.citation: Satya Narain v. District Engineer, P.W.D.  1

anchor.surface_text: Satya Narain v. District Engineer, P.W.D.  1

precedents.case_name: Satya Narain v. District Engineer, P.W.D.
precedents.cited_proposition: plying motor buses by government as commercial activity with profit motive does not make it public service; activity type and profit motive determine if public service or business
precedents.cited_holding: An activity however beneficial to the people ... cannot ... be reasonably regarded as public service if it is of a type which may be carried on by private individuals and is carried on by government with a distinct profit motive.

precedents.citation: Director of Rationing Distribution v. The Corporation of Calcutta  1

anchor.surface_text: Director of Rationing Distribution v. The Corporation of Calcutta  1

precedents.case_name: Director of Rationing Distribution v. Corporation of Calcutta
precedents.cited_proposition: state not bound by statute unless expressly or by implication; rationing and distribution by government was sovereign duty, not trade or business
